module.h: Nouns governed by a progressive verbal noun – genitive or nominative case?
module.p:
In traditional Gaelic, the object of a transitive verb in the progressive was generally in the genitive case eg.
a’ faicinn balaich bhig seeing a little boy
a’ sgrìobhadh na litreach writing the letter
a’ ceannach bhrògan buying shoes
a’ biadhachadh nan con feeding the dogs

However, nowadays there is a noticable tendency to use the nominative for at least some of these uses eg.
a’ faicinn balach beag
a’ sgrìobhadh an litir
a’ ceannach brògan
a’ biadhachadh na coin

The recommended neutral usage in contemporary Gaelic is to use the nominative with an indefinite singular noun and the genitive otherwise ie.
a’ faicinn balach beag
a’ sgrìobhadh na litreach
a’ ceannach bhrògan
a’ biadhachadh nan con

However, the following usages may be appropriate if you are aiming for a more informal, conversational or modern style –
a’ sgrìobhadh an litir
a’ ceannach brògan
a’ biadhachadh na coin

And the following may be appropriate if you are aiming for a more formal, literary or traditional style –
a’ faicinn balaich bhig
a’ sgrìobhadh litreach
